text: A MAN'S HAND, hardworking, rough, lights twigs under a ke Predawn light trickles through the tin walls onto well wo farming tools...hoe, pick, axe, a yoke for an ox. Animist totems and charms hang. We are in a typical Mende FARMER' HUT. Except for the ENGLISH SCHOOLBOOKS on a shelf. The HAND that lit the kettle takes the books off the shel and gently nudges a 14-year-old BOY awake with them. The boy, DIA is his name, groans in sleepy protest. SOLOMON VANDY smiles down at his son.
(in Mende; subtitled) Don't want to be late. The boy sits up, half asleep. Sleepily pulls a shirt over his head. His English is more schooled than his father's.

(in Mende; subtitled) English boys go to school every day? Solomon fills a tin cup of powdered milk. He is a man mar by quiet patience, in the worn trousers and white cotton shirt of a Mende farmer. He hands the cup to the boy.
{in Mende; subtitled) Yes, they do.
(in Mende; subtitled) Not every day.

(in Mende; subtitled) Every day. Just like you. So you can become a doctor. Not walk behind an ox like your father. The boy catches his MOTHER's eye as she breast-feeds his INFANT BROTHER, His twelve-year old sister, N'YANDA, snug with them. She sticks her tongue out at her brother.
Don't worry. She will be joining you next year. JASSIE sends both her men a kiss as they head out.
(in Mende, subtitled) Be careful on the road. Solomon gives his wife an "I know" look.
Solomon and Dia emerge into the early light. Their hut is in a hamlet amidst cassava patches eeked out of the jungl
Don't want to be a doctor. (off Solomon's look) I want to be President. Solomon puts his arm around him. They head into the field

text: Solomon stands stock still, sensing something ... A few chickens flit away without crowing. The oxen are skittish

Go back inside... NOW! Dia is confused. Solomon pushes him into the hut as grinn TEENAGE REBELS appear. One wears a Tupac t-shirt. He rake everything with AK-47 FIRE. Huts. Animals. People. Solomon dives to the ground. VILLAGERS run screaming. Chickens squawk, oxen bray. A rumble. Two mud-splattered PICK-UP TRUCKS with sawed-off roofs crash through the bru full of R.U.F. REBELS, who quickly jump off -- shouting, wielding machetes and automatic rifles, BANDOLIERS OF AMM criss-crossed on their bare chests, GRENADES on their bel Solomon cowers amidst the gunfire, looks around frantical Men and boys are being rounded up. Huts set on fire. Suddenly he is yanked up as two REBELS pull him away-- Jassie exits their hut, infant in her arms, mad with fear
Solomon! He shouts back. Only one word.
Run! She doesn't. She just stands there screaming his name. No Solomon's son and daughter come out of the hut.
Solomon, the rifle choking him, as he's dragged away.

Jassie grabs her son's arm. He resists, staring in anguis at his father. But she tugs at him. And with the two youn children in tow, they join others. Running. Solomon watches them disappear into the bush.

he's rounded up with the OTHER MALES. Only a few able-bod among them. Most are old, skinny men and terrified boys. REBELS prod them with rifles, making them form a line. Al under the watchful sunglasses of an R.U.F. COLONEL. The FIRST VILLAGER is shoved to his knees in front of a t stump. A muscle-bound, SHIRTLESS REBEL with a gleaming AX struts over, his eyes glazed from palm wine and marijuana A second rebel grabs the village man's HAND and places it the stump. The man pulls his hand away. Tupac t-shirt put the Ak-47 to his head. The choice is clear. Your head or your hands. The villager tries to scramble away. RAT-A-TAT! Bullet through his head. The choice is made for him. The next man in line is made to kneel at the stump.

Long sleeve or short sleeve? The other stoned rebels find this hilarious. ON SOLOMON, witnessing his mutilation as terrified WAILS rise around him. The discarded limb is thrown into a bag. The next in line, A STRONG YOUNG MAN, is pushed to the st  10

Not him. He can work. The STRONG YOUNG MAN is herded into a waiting truck. Next comes AN OLD MAN. Shaking, he offers his withered hand. ON SOLOMON. The “crunch" of the axe bores into his soul. The old man is lifted to his feet in clinical shock. Both his forearms end in bloody stumps.

You are the messenger. Spread the word. Guv'ment say da future is in your hands? We say R.U.F. is da future. Revolution is at hand. Solomon is next. He closes his eyes as his hand is placed on the tree stump slick with blood. The Colonel looks him over. Motions the henchmen to stop.
You will need your hands. Solomon is herded into the truck.

A seaplane soars above the bush. At the stick, DANNY ARCH He has seen more in his thirty years than most people hav seen in a lifetime of watching bad television. He scans the landscape then dips toward the estuary of a broad river, eventually splashing to a stop.

Sitting in a lawn chair is COMMANDER RAMBO, a twenty year old R.U.F. fighter with a goatee, wrap-around sunglasses, and a Bob Marley t-shirt. Arrayed behind him, several BODYGUARDS cradle automatic weapons while eating m&m's. A huge BOOM BOX throbs out Tupac's "If I Die 2Nite.”
FAWAZ, a thin Lebanese man, sits beside Archer and eyes t rebels waiting on the riverbank. Murmurs a prayer in Arab
Say one for me, my friend. Archer closes his eyes for a moment, then checks the clip his 9mm Sig-Sauer before tucking it into his belt and pul his shirt-tails over it. Takes a deep breath.
Archer wades in and approaches the group. Imagine teenage on a corner in Bed-Sty carrying AK-47's. Their menace is palpable even as they laugh and pass around a big spliff.
You are Colonel Zero?
I am Commander Rambo.
What happened to Colonel Zero? No response. A few of the rebels giggle.
He was not committed to the revolution. You are here to help us in our struggle against the oppressor.
I'm here to do business. They eye each other in silence.
You have something for me.
First you will show me what you have brought.

No. First you will pay for them. Rambo looks at him with dead eyes. Archer looks back with eyes equally dead. A nasty stand-off. Until Rambo hands him a small, filthy cloth SACK. Archer tips a few rough diamonds into his hand.
(in Krio; subtitled) This is not what was agreed.

(in Krio; subtitled) Maybe I will take the weapons and give you nothing. Archer closes his eyes again, looks back at the seaplane. The cargo door SLIDES OPEN, revealing the muzzle of a M-1 Assault Weapon. Fawaz racks its slide. In response, the Rebels slide the bolts on their weapons.
(in Krio; subtitled) Maybe I'll just do my business with the government. At least the oppressor pays his bills. He turns and starts back toward the plane.
Wait... Wait... Rambo smiles as if it has all been a joke. He reaches int a rusty coffee can and pulls out a huge handful of diamon
This is what you want? Here... So many, I don't know what to do with them all. He gestures for Archer to hold out his hands and pours hi handful.
You bring a satellite dish next time, yah? I want to watch NYPD Blue.
As the seaplane takes off, we see the rebels unloading cr of RPGs with Ukranian markings.
Fawaz gleefully examines their haul.
I'm buying an electronics store. Sit on my ass all day, drink sweet tea and watch dvd's. How about it, Danny? Archer closes his eyes for a moment. He is free.
Fly the plane.

An open pit alluvial mine carved beside a jungle river. M and boys toil knee deep in muddy water. They dig with the hands, shoveling silt into wooden troughs. All under the watchful eyes and guns of R.U.F. REBELS who stand on the banks passing a fat joint rolled in newspaper. Meanwhile, their leader -- CAPTAIN POISON -- spouts twist revolutionary dogma to the diggers:

The Freetown guv-a-ment and their white masters have raped your land to feed their greed! We have freed you! No more slave and master here! We are all brothers! Solomon, his back straining under the weight of a circula sieve, pauses to wipe sweat from his eyes. He's prodded with a rifle, looks up into the fierce FACE of Captain Po
Back to work! Your work is your liberation! Work harder! Dig harder! Solomon turns back to his sieve. ANOTHER DIGGER, peers in his sieve, plucks something out, holds it up in his hand.

Kunaa! All work stops. A rebel comes over. The digger hands him the tiny, milky crystal. A diamond. Without a word, the Commander wraps the stone in a piece of paper. As work resumes, Solomon watches the piece of paper hande off to a RUNNER, who runs it over to the SAME COMMANDER, sits under the shade of a palm frond umbrella reading a Hustler magazine. He stuffs the diamond into his shirt po without even looking at it. Across from Solomon, a 3RD DIGGER glances around. Furtive picks a stone from the sieve and slips it into his mouth. He meets Solomon's eyes. Solomon looks away, keeps workin When he becomes aware of Captain Poison's eyes on him. Solomon tries to shake off the eyes by shaking the sieve. Captain Poison remains staring at him, intently. Then, ca walks over to the 3rd digger with the diamond in his mout AND SHOOTS HIM, at point blank range. Everything stops. Poison turns back to Solomon.
You. Bring him out. Solomon puts down his sieve. Looks at the BODY floating next to him, turning the muddy water red ...
Dear Jassie. I cannot write well enough to put in a letter all the thoughts in my head.  14 15 16 17 18 19
Solomon devours a meager portion of rice gruel in a tin c Others sleep in their fetid clothes on the ground.
Even if I could, my guards would not let me send it.
Solomon sits shivering, looking out at the guards on watc Beyond, a lit TENT where rebels drink and shout back at a satellite TV playing, "Who Wants To Be a Millionaire.”
I do not know where you are. I do not even know where I am.
Jassie and the children are among a group of homeless Men Dia carries the infant. Hearing trucks coming, they scatt into the bush. An R.U.F convoy roars past. After a moment they return to the road.
I only know that my thoughts fly over the mountains to you.
Solomon lays there. Eyes open in a living nightmare.
I will find you, Jassie. I£ it takes my whole life. We will be together.

A high pass. Misty peaks in the distance. A BRILLIANT RED SHAPE comes into view - the bright headdress of a HAUSA SHEPHERD. He carries a spear as he leads a herd of GOATS, bells clinking around their necks. Picking up the rear is Archer, checking a handheld GPS. H SATELLITE PHONE buzzes...
We're two clicks from the strip. What've you got?
Piloted by Fawaz. He speaks into his SAT phone, worriedly looking down on the dense jungle canopy.  20
...Company.
Sure enough, over the hill, comes an armed patrol of ECOM SOLDIERS. The TROOP LEADER approaches Archer.
Papers. Archer fishes out identification. Hands it over.
Elliot Smith, National Geographic.
You are crossing into Liberia.

I have a letter from the Minister of Interior and a Liberian visa as well. (as the Captain studies the papers) Doing a story on the Hausa who, as you know, are allowed to cross the border to get to grazing grounds. Up above, the tiny Plane drones past. The troop leader glances up, then at Archer, who courteously offers an uno pack of cigarettes from his shirt pocket.

Ever read National Geographic? The troop leader ignores him, walks over toa goat and run his hands down the goat's back, under its chin. His hands part a tuft of hair -- revealing a surgically straight li of STITCHES in the goat's skin. Archer feels the shape of the 9mm under his shirt, looks around at the rifles. Too many of them. The troop leader takes out a KNIFE and cuts into the stit The goat squeals a little and kicks angrily. From under t goat's skin, he takes a dozen small, rough DIAMONDS. The troop leader draws his -45 on Archer.
You are under arrest for smuggling.
Now you listen here, my man. JI ama good friend of Minister Somora. He will not be pleased you have interfered with his business.  21 10. Clearly the name of Minister Somora carries some weight.

You know who I am, don't you? What Iam...? I don't think you want to mess with me. Or my friends, eh? (changes his tack) How about I just look the other way and you pocket one or two of those stones. Buy something nice for the wife. Or maybe the mistress, eh? (re the shepherds) Who's going to tell? Them? The shepherds look, uncertain, from Archer to the soldier
No. The troop leader FIRES. One of the shepherds falls dead. The other is cut down as he tries to flee. The leader fro at Archer, whose world has suddenly turned upside down.
We will go back to Freetown and ask Minister Somora how he wishes to thank his business associate.
Archer is handcuffed to a chair. A large, rotund FIGURE enters, silhouetted against the bright windows.
Mr. Minister, there seems to have been a terrible misunderst-- SOMORA BACKHANDS him. Archer's head rocks backwards.
I thought we were friends,
You're right, you're right... I took a little initiative but-- Another SLAP.
Have I not been good to you?

(licks his split lip) Absolutely. And I was planning to cut you in. Haven't I always been--  22 ll. This SLAP knocks Archer's chair backwards to the cement. lies there for a moment. Somora looms over him.
Look... if you wanted to kill me, you would've done it already. So what is it you want me to do? Somora smiles. One of his teeth has a tiny diamond.
The SECRETARY GENERAL of the UN addresses a a full ASSEMB

We propose then to prohibit the direct or indirect import of all rough diamonds from conflict zones to the territory of Member States. He looks at the front row where TWO MEN IN SAVILLE ROW SU sit among the Representatives. One is sandy-haired, 40, h name is SIMMONS. He serves a distinguished-looking older man, 60, with a shock of white hair. His name is DE WENTE

As we know, these stones are only a small percentage of the legitimate diamond industry -- whose trade is crucial to the economies of several emerging nations, and I applaud their support of such a ban. The well-dressed diamond industry reps smile back.
in a reception hall. The Diamond industry REPS and WIVES mingle with UN MEMBERS and other DIGNITARIES. US AMBASSAD WALKER approaches De Wente, holds out his hand.
Mister De Wente... Judd Walker--
Ambassador. Good to finally meet you.
You don't spend much time this side of the Atlantic.
I'm hoping to change that. Perhaps with your help.  24 12.
Mr. De Wente, I'm afraid I don't have much faith in any industry's ability to police itself.

I assure you, sir, we both want the same thing. These 'conflict' stones put the legitimacy of our entire business at risk. De Wente's young blonde WIFE appears at his side. It's ha to decide which is more beautiful, the woman or the two- million-dollar DIAMOND NECKLACE she's wearing.
Darling... This is Ambassador Walker.
How nice to meet you.

(his arm around her) It's my belief, Ambassador, that diamonds should be associated with romance and beauty. Not warfare. Don't you agree? How can the Ambassador not be dazzled? From the glitterin diamonds, we cut to:
Solomon works in the muddy water, his eyes transfixed by sparkling reflections of the river and the swaying trees that seem so unaffected by the brutality beneath.

Dear Jassie. How can it be that one stone is worth more than another? Solomon wills himself back to the soul-killing work. Suddenly, a WATER PUMP BREAKS -- gushing like a fire hose knocking over Solomon and several diggers. Solomon's siev is swept down river. He swims after the SIEVE. Grabs it, sloshing his way back, when he stops... There, underwater, by the riverbank, is something SHINY E to reflect the sun. As the silt washes away, the object remains underwater. A ROCK of a startling pink color. Solomon blinks down at it. The DIAMOND sparkles up at him  25 26 13.

And how can a thing that comes from our mother the earth be so beautiful as to make people want to kill? Solomon looks around. Rebel guards are fixing the pump, shouting at diggers to get back to work. Solomon scoops the diamond into his sieve, covers it with silt. His heart is pounding as he wades back to the bank.
You daydreaming? Get back to work! Solomon nods. Quickly submerges his silt-heaped sieve.
Solomon overturns the sieve. His BARE FOOT catches the diamond.
Solomon raises his hand to get the guards‘ attention. He clutches his abdomen, painfully.
I must go badly. (pleading) Can't hold it in, boss. The guard motions him out. Solomon climbs out, sliding hi second foot carefully. He shuffles to the edge of the jun
Stop. Solomon freezes. Poison searches Solomon. Starting with his hair, his ears, nose. Squeezing his cheeks to see int his mouth. Frisking his pants, unrolling his cuffs.
Lift your foot. Solomon lifts his right foot. They check between his toes
The other. Solomon, looking into Poison's eyes, lifts his left foot. Poison checks between the toes. Satisfied.
Make it quick. CLOSE ON SOLOMON’'S FOOT, as he lowers it. The toes curl into the soft muddy earth, obviously retrieving something  27 28 29 14.

As Solomon squats behind a fallen tree, he eyes the guard through the broad leaves. Quickly, his toes release the muddy gob under his foot. H rubs the mud off it. It's raw beauty is almost unnatural. He glances back to make sure he is unobserved and then ri the cuff off his pants. A CLICK at his head. Solomon slowly looks up ... into the BARREL OF A COLT .45

Give it to me. Solomon doesn't move. What difference does it make? He. awaits the crack of the gun, when: A MORTAR ROUND COMES SCREAMING OUT OF THE JUNGLE. THE EXPLOSION knocks Solomon to the ground. MORE MORTARS. ECOMOG government troops appear, firing automatic weapons. Solomon scrambles over to Poison's ble body, removes the MACHETE from the belt. As shrapnel shreds the greenery, he furiously digs with t machete. Wraps the DIAMOND in his TORN GREEN CUFF and pla it in the hole. When he is STRUCK IN THE HEAD BY A RIFLE BUTT. He falls. ECOMOG SOLDIERS are shouting at him in Mende. Solomon realizes he still holds the machete, lets it drop
Don't shoot! I am not R.U.F! Around him ECOMOG soldiers beat the rebel prisoners with sticks -- in the distance, others are EXECUTED at random.

A convoy of MILITARY TRUCKS rolls through teeming streets Women walk with baskets on their heads, tribal bells jing around their ankles. "Businessmen" in white suits sip Coc Colas outside a hotel. A UN helicopter circles overhead.

Solomon sits chained to other rebel prisoners. He's never been to a city, never seen so many people. It's overwhelm  30 is. He stares at the BEGGARS who run alongside. War orphans, the same age as his own son. He searches every face
Archer looks up from a game of solitaire as REBEL PRISONE are marched past his dank cell.
R.U.F. is coming! Operation Chop Hands! Get ready, my brothers! Archer turns his attention back to his game as the cell d next to his is opened and Solomon is thrown in.

I am not R.U.F. My name is Solomon Vandy! I ama farmer! Archer assesses him. Solomon gives him a hard stare. MORE PRISONERS are brought in, one carried on a stretcher A bandage covers half his face. But when he turns his hea we see that it's Captain Poison. Solomon turns away. Poison lifts his head, squinting through the CELL BARS.
What did you do with it? Solomon doesn't acknowledge Poison.
I'm talking to you! You hear me!? Where is the diamond!? Archer pricks up his ears, but goes on playing solitaire.
A pink diamond. I saw you take it!! Archer's hand, flipping over a card, stops. Listening intently now but careful not to show it.
You are mad. I do not know you.
I saw it with my own eyes!! Poison reaches into his sweat stained shirt, an IVORY CHA from around his neck. Holds it up for all to see.
This big! Biggest I have ever seen!! Solomon just shakes his head, absurdly.  31 16. BUT ARCHER'S EYES...are on the ivory charm, even as he ke playing solitaire. Poison calls to the guards.

I will give a thousand dollars to the man who cuts it out of him! These words do something to Solomon. He stands and rips o his shirt. Then his torn pants. Everything. Until he stan completely naked, facing Captain Poison through the bars.

Where is a diamond? Do you see a diamond!? You devils have taken my family. My home. Everything! Here! Look! What is left!? What is left!? If there is a diamond, then you are the one who has taken it!! Poison lifts his upper body from the stretcher.

Liar! He's a LIAR! The army guards have had enough. They silence Poison with rifle butt to the face. As they drag him away, they give Solomon a “got my eye on you, too" glare. Archer lays out a new hand of solitaire. His eyes move to Solomon, then away. He's heard all he has to. Solomon begins putting his clothes back on. The fury stil in his eyes. Through the bars, he gives Archer a final gl Archer turns away, just keeps playing cards. But then ... ever so carefully ... he picks out the ACE O DIAMONDS. Folds it in half. He gets up and goes to his cell door. Waits until a PRISON GUARD passes by.
Excuse me, brother. Think you could get a message to Minister Somora? The prison guard sees the PACK OF CIGARETTES - and the fo card - that Archer holds through the bars.
Archer walks out into the street, blinks in the sunlight.
is observed in the REARVIEW MIRROR of a parked car by a m with a reddish crewcut. His name is JOOST. FAWAZ appears and hands Archer his hat.  17.
How on earth did you get them to let you go?
There's a farmer in there. He might've found a pink.
And what? You told Somora you'd get hold of it?
I need to contact our friends in London.
I thought we were working for Somora.
Who needs Somora if the pink is real? Archer can tell that Fawaz is holding something back.
~-What?
London wants nothing more to do with you. Fawaz hands him a newspaper clipping.

(reads) "The arrest in Sierra Leone on June One of Daniel Archer, former mercenary and smuggler with ties to the De Wente diamond cartel highlights the trafficking problem blah blah blah..." (crumples it) Fucking hell. He starts off down the street, calling over his shoulder.
His name is Solomon something... Mortgage the plane if you have to -- just get him out.

location: A SHABBY ROOM IN AN APARTMENT HOTEL

text: Dripping wet from a shower, Archer is working the phone.  33 34 35 18.
(on the phone) see Well, can you tell Mr. De Wente Danny Archer called?..... Archer. A...R...
Archer smokes his tenth cigarette.
{on the phone) What time did he say he'd be back?
Archer pounds his fist into a wall.
Yes, he definitely knows what this is in regard to........ Yes.... Yes......... I've been holding.... In frustration, he throws the phone across the room.
Archer leaves the shabby hotel, having changed clothes. H is mobbed by the inevitable swarm of beggars who call him name...."°Arrr-cherrr, Arrr-cherr."
Piss off. He pushes his way past without a trace of compassion.

JOOST, the man we saw surveilling Archer, enters and begi to SEARCH the room, He is professional and brutal -- ripp apart bedding, smashing the phone machine, even slitting carpet into thin strips with a razor blade. It is clear he is looking for something quite small.

Every war zone has a place like this. Soldiers, smugglers opportunists of every stripe stand shoulder to shoulder a oo bar. Bad guys and do-gooders, UN workers and eco- backpackers drink overpriced, watered-down liquor, trade gossip, and hook up for desperate expatriate sex. "Sierra Afrique" blends African drums and electric bass. Every now and then, in the distant hills, the muted SOUND AN EXPLOSION and a rising COLUMN OF SMOKE. No one pays an attention. There is serious drinking to be done.  19. As Archer shoulders his way past, we OVERHEAR brief snipp of conversation. A Nigerian peacekeeper hits on a tipsy blond Red Cross Worker.
This place is nothing but hustlers and dopers. I will take you back to Nigeria. Show you the real Africa.
Is that so? He whispers in her ear and she giggles. Next to them, two SUITS from the Chemical Bank:
~- Fifty thousand in cash. And that's just to get a meeting with him.
The only difference between the crooks who run the country and the R.U.F.-- The AFRICAN BARTENDER (M'ED) serves their drinks.
--is fifty miles. Word on de street dey took Marampa yesterday. He points up into the hills where another explosion rises
Time to reconfirm dose flight reservations, maybe. Archer approaches the bar. His arrival is cause for sever whispered remarks among those in the know.
How de body, Mr. Archer?
Every day above ground, M'ed... (looks to the hills) Your rebel friends planning to visit us one of these days?

Oh, I 'magine dey come do some shopping verrry soon. He laughs darkly. Archer salutes him with his drink. Near an ATTRACTIVE WOMAN taps her swizzle stick on the bar as Oasis' "Party Like It's '99" ends:  20.

This is the Voice of America. Another good day on Wall Street, the Dow Jones up twenty-five points, the Nasdag up forty... In the White House, President Clinton again defended his relationship with Monica Lewinsky-- The woman near Archer speaks up:

Are you listening to this? The world's falling apart and all we hear about is Blowjobgate... Archer turns to MADDY BOWEN. Maddy's a 'handful' whose be belies the kind of fierce intelligence that sends most me running for the door. Archer likes what he sees.
When's the last time the world wasn't falling apart?
Oh. A realist. Been there, done that, got the t-shirt. Is that it?
Danny Archer.
Maddy Bowen.
(appraising her) American.
Guilty.
Americans usually are. Maddy raises an eyebrow. He plays rough. She likes it.
Ouch.
Don't tell me, you're here to make a difference.
And you're here to make a buck. Archer smiles. It's been a long time since he was interes  21.

See that guy? Government minister caught pocketing disaster relief money. Bad move, know why? Wasn't giving a big enough cut to his boss... (points nearby) That one...? Sells AK-47's to the rebels and waits for a cease-fire to buy ‘em at a discount, then after the fighting starts again, sells them back at a profit.
And your point is?
The point is, it's Africa. There is no point. You want another?
Vodka. Rocks. Archer catches Med's eye -- who nods approvingly at Maddy
M'ed. Same again.
You were born here?
Rhodesia.
You were there during the war? Must have been rough.
(offering nothing) Loved it.
And you're a smuggler.
Am 1?
Somehow I don't take you as the UNICEF type. Archer just smiles.
I was going to say 'soldier-of- fortune' but it's such a cliche.  36 22.
How about hired gun. People seem to like that one.
Diamonds?
What if I told you I was a missionary.
(laughs) For De Wente?
It's not just rude to ask those kind of questions, Ms. Bowen, it's also dangerous.
I'll take my chances. (leans closer) So... tell me about blood diamonds. And then, suddenly, Archer gets it. His face turns to sto
..-You're a journalist.
That's right. Archer stands up from his stool.
Piss off. He throws some money onto the bar. Maddy follows him out.

De Wente Diamonds closed its buying offices here to avoid U.N. sanctions. But they're using cut-outs to buy stones from the rebels on the cheap. That way nobody accuses them of profiting from the war --which they clearly are.
I'm shocked.  37 38 39 40 23.
You got popped trying to go free- lance, so they cut you loose and let you rot in jail. (grabs him) Don't you want a chance to get even? He keeps walking.
Hey, wait a second. She grabs his arm. Moves closer.
(the slightest sexual promise) Help me out here... He can't help but give a bitter laugh.
Maddy, right? (she nods) ... Usually I liked to be kissed before I get fucked. He walks off, leaving her to the inevitable swarm of begg
Archer walks in and sees the wreckage of his life.
Archer stares at himself in the remains of his mirror. He opens a bottle of vodka and chugs it.
South African Security Forces BREAK DOWN a door and roust sleeping middle-aged ANC supporter from his bed. His wife SCREAMS as Archer puts a bag over the man's head.
Archer takes a long pull of vodka and tosses the bottle. With a pliers he grips a false crown atop A BACK TOOTH.
The Black prisoner is naked, tied to a chair. We do not s what is being done to him. Instead, we study Archer's fac as he watches. 37 38 39 40  41 42 43 44 24.
Bright drops of blood drip into the sink. Ignoring the incredible pain, Archer rips out the crown. Into his palm, he taps a bloody ROUGH DIAMOND.
A crowded street of little STOREFRONTS with hand-painted signs of diamonds. Street merchants lick their palms and hiss as Archer passes.
Little more than a corrugated shack. We see Archer haggli and reluctantly accepting less cash than his stone is wor
Joost is waiting in the road, making no attempt to hide.
Joost. JOosT Long time, mate.
How's Alice?
Well, thanks.
Tim must be in college.
Big kids, big problems... you know.
Company's doing well? Joost Can't complain. Eleven wars on the continent, business is brisk. {looks at him) Heard you had a bit of trouble in the bush.

Somora called you. JOOsT Minister Somora and the Colonel are old friends. 41 42 43 44  as 46 47 48 49 25. Joost smiles. Archer takes out a pack of cigarettes, offe one. Joost demurs. Archer pats his pockets for a match.
Got a light? Joost reaches into his pocket, takes out a lighter. As he leans in to light Archer's cigarette--

KNEE, LOW-PUNCHES HIM IN THE GROIN, SWEEPS HIS LEGS OUT F
UNDER HIM, AND THEN STOMPS HIM IN THE KIDNEYS.

text: Next time the Colonel has a question. All he has to do is ask. He walks away, leaving Joost writhing in the street.
Archer pays cash for a round-trip ticket to London.

The global nexus of the diamond trade. A cab pulls up and Archer gets out, wearing a suit. ACROSS THE STREET, a small group of PROTESTERS with signs that read, "No Blood Diamonds," and "DTC Funds Torture." One sign has a drawing of a diamond ring on a severed fin
Archer passes through security: fingerprint reader, scann the works. He is buzzed through an ANTI-BALLISTIC DOOR.
He glances at the well-lit display cases -- one of which features a replica of the 530-carat "Star of Africa".

plays a Ridley Scott commercial for De Wente diamonds. Romantic. Flashy. A young man proposes to a beautiful blushing girl. An older couple celebrate their anniversar Rappers wearing ‘bling' on the Grammy Awards.
Mister Simmons will see you now.
ROLAND SIMMON'S office is tasteful and inoffensive. So is Roland Simmons. We last saw him at the UN.  26.
Come in. Come in. Tea?
No thanks.
So. What brings you to London?
Reg... Spare me. Simmons adjusts the trousers of his bespoke suit. He'd ra talk about anything but business, but if Archer insists:

A month ago, officers of this company sat in front of the United Nations and pledged to uphold a ban on “conflict” diamonds. (looks out the window) We are no longer accepting the stones you supply. I'm truly sorry you've come all this way, but our relationship is officially over. Archer looks around. Realizes.
You're recording this. Simmons smiles. Archer doesn't give a shit. Record this.
You're losing your hold on the global market. Big finds in Russia, Canada. You need me more than ever. Simmons glances at his watch.
You don't plan to lecture me on the trade, do you?

The trade? Oh, that has such a nicer ring to it than “cartel,” "Cartel" is for Columbian drug dealers and oil sheiks. It's so... unbecoming. Archer stands and walks to a FRAMED WALL PHOTO of the distinguished older MAN whom we last saw at the UN.
But since it's just the two of us, Reg, let's cut the bullshit. (MORE)

You've got eight-billion-dollars- worth of stones gathering dust in those vaults downstairs. (leans forward) If you didn't keep 'em off the market, that rock on your finger would cost less than your shoes.
Fine. Write a book. Tell the BBC.

(continuing over him) --Which is why it would be a shame if, say, another company got all the press, not the mention the profits from the largest pink ever to find its way to market~- This pulls Simmons up short.
You're bluffing.
Probably. But if I'm not, you're going to be the one having to explain to Mr. De Wente how it happened. He stands and starts out.
Nice talking to you, Reg. Love the new hairline. Simmons holds up a hand, as if to say, ‘wait a second.' H flips a switch and MUSIC fills the room.
What are you asking?
Ten percent of market as a finder's fee.
Five.
Seven.
Agreed.
Always a pleasure doing business.  50 51 28. He turns and walks out. Simmons picks up the phone.
Get me De Wente.
Solomon walks out of prison to find Fawaz waiting.
Solomon Vandy?
What do you want?
Some friends of mine thought you look like an honest man. Fawaz hands him a wad of cash and walks away.

An abandoned school. Men, women with babies swaddled in tribal cloth. They are impatient, unruly. Solomon sees the line snaking around the block. He walks casually toward the front, acting as if he knows someone.
Hello my brother. How's de body?
Do I know you? Solomon insinuates himself beside him in line.
Sure, sure. We met at your cousin's wedding. Don't you remember? Another refugee, farther back in line, calls out angrily.
Back in line! Other refugees join in calling "end of the line," etc. Solomon ignores them, focusing on the man beside him.
--and how is the happy couple? The angry refugee GRABS Solomon by the arm.
Hey, mon, who you think you are?  52 29. Solomon turns on him with quiet menace.
If you don't let go, I will break your arm. Then I will break your head. The wild look in Solomon's eye is truly terrifying. The m recoils in fear. The other refugees stop their grumbling.
Hundreds of NAMES, posted on reams of paper cover the wal Solomon searches the list methodically. Even as he's shov and pushed, he holds his ground. The names he seeks are n there.
Dear Jassie. Can it be that no one in our country has a home? He looks around for someone in authority. Hears an Africa SOLDIER speaking Mende.
(in Mende, subtitled) Please, I must talk to someone. My family's name is not on the list. The soldier, who is being yelled at by five other people simultaneously, replies angrily in subtitled Mende:
Go to Kambe, there is another list.
I have been to Kambe, and Mombolo, and Tibili, and--
Talk to the whites. He points to a harried RED CROSS OFFICIAL who fields an onslaught of questions. Solomon pushes his way to him.
Excuse me, sir, my name is--
--Check the list.
I have checked the lists. The Brit shouts to be heard over the tumult.  53 54 55 30.
You have to file papers with the Office of Refugees!
I have filed papers!
Then God help you, man. Because I can't. Solomon wants to scream at him, but the Brit is right.
Solomon sits in the middle of the crowded street. Bereft.
They told us freedom would make our country into a paradise. But it has turned it into a sewer instead.

location: SOMEWHERE IN THE SIERRA LEONE HILLS

text: Dia, Jassie and his sister wait for food at an R.U.F. out A rebel wearing a DOO-RAG eyes them. Dia glares as the ma offers his twelve year-old sister a Milky Way bar. Jassie pulls her daughter away but ANOTHER SOLDIER puts h arm around her waist -- pinning her arms behind her back.

Maybe you are my new wife! Doo Rag starts to lead N'yanda away. Dia flings himself a the rebel, but OTHERS jump him and begin to beat him with their rifle butts. Jassie's screams are drowned out by th laughter of their tormentors. Dia, meanwhile, is lifted up and THROWN into the back of truck with several other TEENAGE BOYS.
Archer walks to the curb. Joost is waiting beside a Merce His eyes are still black-and-blue behind sunglasses.
He wants to see you.
I'm going back to Sierra Leone, actually. Two Square-jawed MERCENARIES emerge from the Mercedes, th outline of handguns obvious beneath the tails of their sh  56 57

I don't suppose, ‘I'm sorry,‘ would suffice? Joost smiles thinly. The mercenaries unobtrusively hem in Archer on both sides. He expects to be pummeled at any moment. Instead they politely open the car door.
After you.
The Mercedes winds it way into the South African Veldt, passing elegant stables, grape orchards and cricket pitch
Archer expects to be beaten at any moment. It doesn't hap

head_text.subj: DRIVING DEEPER INTO THE VELDT S7A

text: The landscape has grown barren. At a gate lined with barb wire, a sign -- “Executive Outcomes" -- is flanked by arm soldiers wearing crimson berets, who wave them on. They follow a deserted dirt road, until--
materializes out of nowhere. After making a perilously cl pass, it flies away.
The Mercedes glides to a stop beside a spreading acacia.
Looks like he could still lead a platoon on a fifty mile forced-march in hostile conditions. In fact, he still doe
Hello, Danny.
Sir.
You look better than Joost here.
A misunderstanding between friends. The Colonel chuckles and pours him a marula martini.  32.
(raising his glass) Here's to us and those like us--
(finishing the toast) --Damn few. They sip.
I want you to come back.
Thanks but I prefer not to.
We'll be coming your way soon. Our lawyers are in conversation with the government of Sierra Leone, such as it is. Archer smiles darkly.
They want us to take back the diamond mines and I need someone who knows his way around up there. Archer just takes another sip. The Colonel studies him.
According to our Minister Somora, you've got something in the works. Something. ..pink.
(dismissive) The fantasy of some Mende farmer...
There is the small matter of payment on some RPG's. You haven't forgotten who arranged that shipment from our Ukranian friends...?
But who is it, I wonder, who tipped off the ECOMOG to the goat routine? The Colonel's tone loses some of its warmth.
Pay your debt in cash or come back to work. Your choice.  59 60 33.
If I had a hundred grand you think I'd still be on this continent?
(laughs) Oh, Danny... You'll never leave. You're African to the bone. (dismissing him) Joost will see you back to Cape Town.
I appreciate that. Thank you.
We'll meet again soon?
No disrespect, sir, but I hope not.
You think selling weapons is better than using them? At least when it's you pulling the trigger, you know you're not the target. The Colonel chuckles, and gives Joost a subtle nod.
They approach the parked Mercedes. Archer turns to Joost.

Okay, just get it over with. The two mercenaries grab Archer's arms. Joost smiles sympathetically and then begins to beat the shit out of h INT. THE “EXECUTIVE HOTEL” - FREETOWN - DAY 60 Half of its SIGN has been blown away. A filthy red carpet leads to a colonial facade. Solomon, in a red vest that serves as a uniform, carries businessman's bags. As the businessman gets into a cab, a pack of Marlboro 100's falls out of the man's pocket.

Dear Jassie. It has been so many weeks and I still cannot find you. Solomon waits until the cab pulls away. Then he kneels an pockets the cigarettes.  61 62 63 64 65 34. INT. THE “EXECUTIVE" HOTEL - LATER 61 Solomon carries bags up a back stairs. He checks to see i anyone is watching then rifles the bags for anything of v
At an open-air market, Solomon exchanges the cigarettes a other stolen items for hard currency.
The city is loud and crowded and dirty. I miss the farm and cannot help wondering what has happened to the cassava crop.
Solomon bribes a UNICEF OFFICIAL with the currency. He walks past rows of civilian casualties, many of them children. He forces himself to smile at each face he pass
Places like this define every city in the third world. Solomon has taken residence in the rusted hull of an old car. It is bare except for an extra shirt folded neatly.
Most of all I miss our family all together in the hut at night, the sound of the childrens’ breathing, and your warmth beside me. He lights a candle before a wooden animist statue.
Whenever I feel myself losing hope, I think of these things and I know it will be all right.
Dia sits in a dark hut along with several TEENAGE CAPTIVE The door is flung open and GUARDS brutally drive them out form a line. Dia stands, terrified, in a driving rain.
Your mothers and fathers are dead. Your brothers and sisters are dead. You are dead too. But you will be reborn with us. We are your family now.  66 67 68 69 70 71 35.
Dia and others are being taught to fire an AK-47.
Dia carries a plastic jug of palm wine through the rebel camp. Handing it an older guerilla, he inadvertently SPIL some on the man's t-shirt. The man begins to BEAT him.
Dia is held down by two rebels as a cut is opened in his and an unidentified powdery drug is poured into the cut.
Dia is bouncing off the walls of the hut -- stoned out of his mind. Several teenage boys are similarly wasted.

Archer gets out of a cab, carrying his bag. His face is swollen and sunglasses cover a black eye. A MILITARY JEEP is parked in front of his hotel. Several ECOMOG troops loiter, perhaps waiting for him, perhaps no Not taking any chances, Archer turns away. EXPLOSIONS LIKE DISTANT THUNDER rumble through the stifli night as he walks. A car is on fire. A sense of things growing out of control. A YOUNG AFRICAN WOMAN, miniskirt, big earrings beckons hi
You lonely tonight, Archer? (pulls down her top) I'm safe. No HIV. You use condom.
Half of it is burnt. People crowd the remaining half, Grinking as heavily as ever. The African Techno-Beat thro Archer gets Med's attention at the bar, sets down his bag
Mind looking after this for me? (M'ed nods) ...Like what you've done to the place.
Fokking R.U.F. try to hit the guv'ment building ‘cross da street. Shit, mahn, half da people heah be R.U.F. (MORE)
(hands him the usual) Good for business doh. Ever'body drink much as dey can ‘fore de rebels come an drink up de rest.
Might be time to get your family out, my friend. The facade of Med's professional joviality disappears.

And go where, mahn? Jus‘ fire up de chopper and fly away like you people? No, mahn, dis my country. We here long ‘fore you came and long after you gone. He stares at Archer, his eyes a tragic mask of defiance a despair. He turns away. Fawaz approaches. He is a nervous wreck.
Oh, my God, are you all right?
Where's the farmer?
He found a job at a hotel. Spends all his time at the refugee offices. Not exactly the behavior of a man in possession of a priceless stone. Another EXPLOSION in the distant hills. Fawaz flinches.

The main road to Masiaka is cut in three places. The government's gonna fall any second, and I'm following some delusional farmer. Archer sees Maddy through the crowd. She's standing apart looking somewhat dazed as she moves slowly to the music.
The man was a digger. The odds of him getting away with even a small stone is zero. They slit you open alive just for sweating.
I think Somora is looking for me.  37.
(really worried now) Allah forfend...
(moving away) dust stay on the farmer.

But-- Archer has already begun heading toward Maddy. She sees h coming and watches him walk toward her. They meet in the middle of a crowded dance floor. All around them, sweaty bodies are swaying to the African beat.
Am I supposed to kiss you or fuck you? I can't remember.
How about you dance with me.
Should I ask what happened to your face? He takes her hand and leads her into the surging crowd.
I guess not. They dance as best they can in the crush.
This is insane. I'm drunk in an African bar dancing with a mercenary.
What would they say in Ohio?
Chicago.
++-You can tell a lot about someone by the way they dance.
Then you can probably tell right away that I can't dance. They look at each other.  38.
In Mozambique, you were part of a search-and-destroy unit targeting ANC leaders. Then in Angola, you hooked up with De Wente and started trading guns for diamonds.
Is this on the record?

But you blew it all getting greedy and trying to go it alone. Why? He doesn't answer. They are looking at each other. The music is pounding. Sweat is pouring off both of them but neither bothers to wipe it away. They keep
So you're, what, a Nihilist? Opportunist? Scumbag?
Maybe I just wasn't breast-fed in childhood.
You think I've never met people like you?
I think you get off on people like me.
Fuck you.
That, too. dancing, their faces very close.
What I'll...never understand... is how...you can...compartmentalize... human suffering. He stops dancing. Looks at her.
Thanks for the dance. He walks away.  39.
He lights a cigarette. She appears and stands quietly bes him. Together they watch the distant explosions.
I didn't actually hurt your feelings? He takes a long drag. Exhales.
How long you been in Africa?
Pour months. Before that Kosovo.
Okay. How many Blacks do you know back in the States -- besides the girl who cleans your house and the man who picks up your garbage?
What's that got to do with it?

I know Blacks. Grew up with ‘em, fought with ‘em. Behind the calm eyes and the gentle smile, they're burning with hate for what we've done to ‘em. They hate you, hate me, hate each other and hate themselves. And your bleeding heart isn't gonna stop ‘em butchering each other. Half the continent is starving and the rest is dying of AIDS while their leaders sell medicine to build palaces and drive Mercedes.
That doesn't make it right.

No it doesn't. But apart from a few do~gooders who show up for a week with their flak jackets, their laptops, and their little bottles of hand sanitizer the White world doesn't give a fuck about the Black world. Look at Sudan. Look at Rwanda. Your country loses thirty-four marines in Somalia and then does nothing as a million people die. Except put pictures of starving children on TV to flagellate their guilty conscience. (MORE)
(shakes his head) So someone's got to do the dirty work~- you think America doesn't sell arms or hire professionals? You call them ‘contractors’. I sell guns. If I don’t, somebody else will.
The law of the jungle. (sighs) If only I had a nickel for every piece-of-shit who uses it to justify his existence. He turns to look at her, her face radiant with sweat.
I like your smell.
Well, that makes me weak at the knees.
It's all gonna blow any minute. You should get out.
An ECOMOG relief column leaves in the morning. What about you?
Business to finish up.
What could possibly be worth staying and getting yourself killed over? He looks at her, offers a grim smile.
Oh. Right. He indicates the bare "wedding ring" finger of her left h
Tell me you never dreamt of having a sparkly diamond of your very own. (as he walks away) +..Peace,
Solomon emerges from his rusted hulk to find Archer waiti Archer looks as if he's been up all night avoiding the Minister's troops -- which in fact he has.  41.
What did you do, bury it? Solomon instinctively looks to see if anyone is listening
I would have buried it.
(heart racing) What are you talking about? Archer removes his sunglasses, looks Solomon in the eye.
What am I talking about?
I must go to work. Archer follows as Solomon walks through the shantytown.
My friend Fawaz paid an awfully large bribe to get you out of jail.
I will pay Mister Fawaz back. He has my word. And now you have my word. And we have finished speaking. Solomon runs for a crowded bus. Archer watches him disapp

Solomon is carrying bags for Western businessmen frantic get out of Freetown before it's too late. Depositing their bags in a taxi, he walks back into the l to find Archer leaning against a post, smoking a cigarett
Why would that R.U.F. captain with the bandaged eye make up such a story. Solomon again tries to ignore him.

What are you going to do, sell it yourself? To who? For how much? You need help, friend, whether you want it or not. Another porter is eavesdropping. Solomon escapes into the alley beside the hotel, turns on Archer.  42.
I know who you are. And what you are. Men like you have turned my country into a land of thieves and killers. I do not need your help.
What if I could help find your family? At these words, something feral appears in Solomon's eyes
What do you know of my family?
The relief agencies are useless, the hospitals are overwhelmed. There are other ways.
Liar!
I know people. White people. Solomon LUNGES -- pinning Archer against the wall. Archer could fight. He doesn't.
The...right...stone-- Solomon wants nothing more than to strangle him, but he a intuits Archer might be his only hope. He relaxes his gri

-~-can buy anything. Information. Safety. Even freedom. But a big stone doesn't stay secret. The minute you show it, your life is worthless. I'm guessing the only reason you're still alive is because you haven't told anyone where it is. Right? Archer's pitch -- fueled by desperation -- is mesmerizing
The last pink to come out of Africa fetched ten million dollars. I know because I carried it out. You know what I got for it? He opens his shirt. A HUGE SCAR crosses his chest.  76 43.
I was lucky. I learned that a man will do anything for a diamond.
You would say anything. How can I trust you--?

head_text.subj: NEARBY, THE CRUMP OF AN EXPLOSION, FOLLOWED BY THE CHATTE
OF AUTOMATIC WEAPONS...FROM A BLOCK OR TWO AWAY.

text: Hear that? It's started. They must've snuck into the city overnight. (looks at Solomon) What's it gonna be, friend?
Three cut-down trucks of Rebels SQUEAL into view and begi spraying everything with automatic weapons.
Yes or no. A whole life can change with a single syllable.
Yes. A TRUCK COMES CAREENING AROUND THE CORNER. Archer pushes Solomon as the wall behind them is stitched with bullets.
Go. GO! They begin to run.

Their fates suddenly joined by the need to stay alive. And death lurks at every corner. Bands of teenagers roam the streets, FIRING AUTOMATIC WEA at anything that moves. Signs, store windows, cars. Urban Rap dopplers past as trucks with boom boxes speed by. At an intersection, an impromptu ROADBLOCK. People are pu out of cars and beaten while their cars are set on fire. Archer and Solomon double back and sprint past the Execut hotel where a gang of Rebels are entering. From inside co the sound of SCREAMING and more GUNFIRE. People are being taken -- black and white alike -- and fo into trucks. MINISTER SOMORA is led away at gunpoint.  77 78 79 44. Women are dragged by the hair into alleyways. A man is th out of a fourth-story window. In fact, it was Much worse than anything we can ever show Archer _and Solomon continue to run for their lives. Storefronts are looted. It's impossible to tell the rebel from the civilians. Adults carry televisions. Two men car a barca-lounger. Teenage boys wear womens' wigs and throw molotov cocktails made from Swedish vodka. Rebel teenager are sacking The Beach Bar -- drinking everything in sight Me'd lies dead, splayed across the bar. Archer and Solomon run through the darkening streets as rockets light up the sky. A_gun battle between retreating government soidiers and advancing rebels traps them in a crossfire. They dive into a restaurant doorway, taking refuge with o huddled, terrified, on the floor. Windows are shot out as rounds rip in and plaster rains down on their heads. After a deafening moment -- quiet. Archer watches through crack in the door as ECOMOG troops are lined up against a wall and executed.

Archer and Solomon set off again They do their best to stay in shadows, hugging the walls pock-marked buildings, as they try to sneak past the rovi patrols and trucks filled with men, and out of the city.
How...much.... farther?
Sooner...or...later...we'll be in the bush.
They are still running. Both men are exhausted, filthy with soot and sweat, their chests heaving. But neither even considers stopping. Arou them, the houses are becoming fewer.
And then another. Nothing beyond except a tangle of banan trees, ruined cassava groves, and the densely-covered hil  80 81 82 4s.
There--! With renewed energy, they pick themselves up and run:

Sends them DIVING into a ditch. Three R.U.F. soldiers are setting up a machine gun. Solom looks around wildly. There is nowhere to go. If they are still there by daybreak, they will be discovered. If they try to run, they will be shot. A look of resolve steals over Archer's face as he reaches into his boot for his knife. Without a backward glance, h slithers out of the ditch.

head_text.subj: THE KILLING OF THE THREE SOLDIERS 80

text: Is a deadly ballet. One's throat is slit, the second is gutted. But his weapon FIRES -- alerting the third soldie who whirls -- just in time for his body to be stitched by rounds from the dead man's AK-47 -- which Archer now hold It has all happened in a matter of seconds. But the gunfi has alerted more soldiers from nearby.
Archer and Solomon take off into the field -~ as TRACERS soon begin to streak past.

head_text.subj: AT LAST THEY BREAK INTO THE BRUSH 81

text: Vines whipping against their faces, thorns ripping their hands and clothes -- until long after the gunfire has sto At_last they stop. Bent over double. Gasping for breath in the humid night. Alive. The two men look at one another. They could never articul it, but both intuitively know this will be the defining journey of their lives.

In Cambodia, in El Salvador, in Sudan as in Sierra Leone, the image of a downtrodden, dispossessed multitude travel on foot toward an uncertain end has become the signature image of our time. It is the Age of the Refugee.  46. Archer and Solomon trudge amidst the throng. Ox-drawn car and thousands of shuffling feet churn up a sea of dust.
Where are we going?
There's a relief camp in Port Loki. Journalists will have access to a SAT-phone. I'll have Fawaz meet us with the plane.
I have agreed to nothing. Archer looks straight ahead as he walks.
You will.

In a soccer stadium, ECOMOG soldiers distribute stacks of GRAIN bearing the UNICEF stencil, BOXES of MEDICAL SUPPLI Archer is outside the fence, talking to a guard. He is buffeted by hordes of refugees trying to get to the food.
~-I work for the Cape Town Herald. My wallet, my credentials, everything's still in Freetown. We barely got out with our lives...
Back away from the fence-- Archer gives up. Solomon has been watching.
You are not a journalist.
I'm trying to get us out of here.
It is as I said. You will say anything. Archer sees JOURNALISTS. He waylays an Australian CAMERAM
Hey, mate. I'm looking for somone you might know. Name's Maddy Bowen. American. If you've met her you wouldn't forget it.  84
I know her.
Could you tell her Archer's here and I've got the story she wants.
I'm out of here in an hour. If I see her before then, I'll tell her.
Thanks. Cheers. 84 Archer and Solomon are broiling under a relentless sun. Solomon searches every passing face. Archer dozes.
You got out.
Hello, Maddy. This is Solomon Vandy.
How do you do? (to Archer; all business) I'm on deadline and I've been waiting four hours to use a SAT-phone. What do you want to tell me. Archer moves her out of Solomon's earshot.
An outfit named Star Mines is buying blood diamonds.
And...?
De Wente has no visible ties to Star -- but through a maze of crossholdings and offshore banks, they own it. In violation of the very trade embargo they pledged to uphold.
You have proof of this. (he nods) And you'll go on record? He looks at her.  85 48.
If you help me out.
I knew it.

Before you say anything -- the man is a Mende farmer. His village was burned to the ground. He was forced to work the mines, but his family fled -- wife and three children. He's been trying to find them but he's drowning in red tape. Maddy looks again at Solomon.
How do you even know this man?
I know him. Maddy looks back at Archer.
You're using me.
And you're using me. Isn't that how it works? (leaning in) You want to make a difference, Maddy? Start with this man. You've got access to U.N. databases, you know all the N.G.0O.'s.
Look around, Archer. What difference does helping one man make? He looks at her.
Jesus. Did I really say that? Maddy's eyes remain on his, conflicted, as we HEAR the BE OF HELICOPTER BLADES...
LOOKING DOWN on a sweep of grassland on which a sea of flapping white tents suddenly appears...thousands of them
There it is.  86 87 a9.
Solomon, Archer and Maddy have hitched a ride on a U.N. chopper. Solomon's never been up in one. He stares down a the sprawling tent city below.
At the moment, the second largest refugee camp in Africa.
My wife is here? In Guinea? Maddy reads from the computer manifest in her hand.
Jassie Vandy, Kono District. Crossed into Guinea six weeks ago.
Six weeks. And my children? Maddy hesitates, folds the manifest, then just nods.
You would have found them. Sometimes it takes a year before new manifests reach the field offices. (glances at Archer) I was lucky to get access to the UNHCR database.
I do not know how to thank you. What can Maddy say? She nods.

Archer, Solomon and Maddy step off the chopper to find-- SEA OF HUMANITY behind a CHAIN FENCE stretching for miles WORKERS with World Food Program armbands unload supplies REFUGEES rush the fence, pressing forward, shouting.

This is what a million people look like. Solomon stares. These are his people. CLOSE ON ARCHER taking it all in. He's seen pretty much everything there is to see in life. But no one is unaffec  88 50.

You might catch a minute of this on CNN somewhere between weather and sports. As they approach the fence, Solomon sees that many of the refugees are AMPUTEES. Some reaching through the chain li with stumps of arms. Solomon's heart is pounding.

It says they're in Sector Two. Solomon follows as Maddy shows her BADGE to a UN GUARD, w reads her slip of paper and points out the right directio Archer stares through the fence at two KIDS, each with on leg, yet managing to kick a plastic jug back and forth. Other amputees stare sullenly. A sign reads, “NO PHOTOS F

A WRINKLED OLD MAN blows his lips at Archer through the f Archer walks on. The old man shadows him. Until Archer realizes the fellow is gesturing to the cigarettes in his shirt pocket. Archer takes out a cigarette, is about to slip one through the fence -- When he sees the man has no hands. Grimly, Archer sticks the cigarette in the man's mouth. Then moves on.
A FRENCH UN GUARD relays the paper to an AFRICAN WFP MONI
Stay at the fence. Quarantine. Solomon grips the fence, watching the WFP monitor as he disappears into the teeming mass. Archer has rejoined them. He notices Maddy's expression.

What's wrong? Maddy shakes her head. But Archer can tell she's keeping something from him. Solomon catches sight of the WFP monitor. He has a woman with him. A woman carrying a little boy and a young girl.
Jassie ...? (and then he's sure) Jassie! JASSIE!  51. Jassie hears her name, looks up through the hordes of peo
Solo! SOLO!!

Solomon's face morphs from disbelief to joy as Jassie run through a crush of bodies to him -- Their fingers GRASP each others through the fence. They r their hands over each others faces, unable to speak. Solomon looks at the one-year-old in her arms, an infant when last he saw him. He touches him through the fence. The girl, silent, offers a weak smile. She's seen too muc Then Solomon looks around, puzzled.
Dia? (to Jassie, in Mende) Where is Dia? The boy is nowhere in sight.
Where is my son? Watching this, Archer turns to Maddy.
He has a son who goes to school, reads English.
There were only two children listed on the manifest.
--What? Maddy turns away, her eyes brimming. AT THE FENCE, Solomon reads Jassie's eyes.
Where is he!? She rubs her cheek against his hand, her body trembling.

They...took him. Solomon looks at her, incomprehensibly. And the words com out in a flood of Mende - that breaks into a WAIL of grie  89 52. Solomon drops to the ground as if every muscle in his bod had been cut. He struggles for breath. Archer cannot watch their grief ... yet cannot turn away.
Fuck this A GUARD tries to pry Solomon's hands from the fence, but won't let go. Sensing trouble, the guard calls ANOTHER GU over. Both of them try to pull Solomon from the fence.
Let them out. Jassie doesn't let go of her husband's hands.
Solo ... Solo Solomon starts shaking the fence.
Let them out! The guards begin to beat his hands with their rifle butts But Solomon keeps shaking the fence as if to uproot the s posts.
Archer puts himself between Solomon and the guards.
Get off him! A guard points his rifle and shouts in an unknown dialect
Fine! Just get off him!
Archer and Maddy ride in silence. Solomon stares out the chopper window. His knuckles bandaged. Devoid of emotion.
They're afraid some of the refugees might be rebels. They won't be released until there's a cease-fire. I'm sorry. Solomon stares out at the distant fog-shrouded mountains.  90 91 53.

What you want, Mister Archer, is beyond those hills. That is where I buried it. Archer's heart skips a beat. What was only spoken of is n real. Maddy looks at Solomon, his face knotted in grief. And th back at Archer. She is putting the pieces together.
Maddy marches away from the helicopter.
Maddy, wait... He grabs her arm. She wrenches free of his grip.
I didn't take his son! Don't pin that on me!
I pin it on all of us. Especially you.
Yah, we fucked the black man. My father did and my grandfather before him. Now the black man fucks himself. Tell me something I don't know. Tired, furious, done with sparring, she walks off.

Solomon and Archer huddle beside a fire. Around them are hundreds of fires, each with huddled figures silhouetted. Solomon's sharpens the blade of a MACHETE with a whetston Archer pores over a MAP with a flashlight.
You say the mine is near the Moa River. Where exactly on this map? Solomon's eyes remain on the machete blade.
I do not need a map.
Well, I do. We follow his finger ON THE MAP as he talks.  92 54.
We're here.... The press convoy is going to Kailahun. Diamond mines are here. Where did you bury it? He looks over and sees that Solomon is CUTTING a line up arm with the machete, drawing blood.
You understand, when we get to Kailahun, we're gonna have to go overland. You better damn well be able to find it. Solomon is lost in a world of ritual.

(almost to himself) My son is a very good student. He walks five miles to the Sisters' school every morning to study English. He is going to be a doctor one day. The pain of self-injury is an attempt to inure himself to the pain of loss. He turns away to stare into the fire. Archer has to walk away.

houses the paltry assortment of journalists. Archer walks past the guards with a wave of the finger. They assume -- because he is white -- that he belongs there. MADDY is hunched over a portable typewriter, typing with fingers. Archer leans over her shoulder to read.
",.,in the ninety degree heat, farmer Solomon Vandy drops to his knees against the chain-link fence--" Maddy whirls around. Archer finishes the sentence.
"--rattling the wire with his powerful hands...”
(defensive) ..-What?
Nothing.
You think I'm exploiting his grief.  55. Archer just looks at her. She loses it.

You think I like being here? Do you have any idea what I could make back in the states writing garbage about movie stars--? (righteous fury) All anybody sees here are victims. Not people. With faces. And lives. They deserve a voice. (shaking her head) And the world deserves to know where the things they buy come from. And how much they really cost. (turns away) So get out of my face and let me work. Archer watches her work for a moment. Rubs his eyes.

...-Solomon thinks his son is going to be a doctor one day. (she looks up) What's the life expectancy for infants in a camp like this? What's going to happen to a twelve year-old girl? That diamond is the only chance he's got of getting his family out.
You expect me to believe you give a rat's ass about his family.
No. I'm just exploiting his grief. She glares at him, then looks away. There are inherent contradictions in both their intentions.
I need to get to Kailahun. The only way now is with a UN convoy. I'ma TV journalist and he's our cameraman. Maddy's shaking her head. She won't do it.
No.

Fawaz spills a bag of rough diamonds onto the counter.

where a CERTIFICATE OF ORIGIN bearing a Liberian seal is signed, stamped and affixed to a WOODEN BOX NAILED SHUT.

You really want to think about it? Up ahead, Solomon stares up at a particularly bright star
Kya kwayera taarig.

Looms out of the jungle as they walk a narrow track. Pornographic GRAFFITI has been spray-painted on the churc and "West Side Niggaz." HEADLESS BODIES hang from the tre

Where are you from? Have you come from America? Do you have CD's? A GENTLE VOICE calls out.

Don't be bothering the people now. Let them come in. The children instantly obey. BENJAMIN KAPANAY appears in doorway. He is a tall, sixty-five year-old distinguished- looking Mende with a trim white beard.
(in Mende; subtitles) Thank you, Ubani. You can leave them here. I take responsibility.
{in Mende; subtitles) Good. Now they are your problem. The Kamajors back away, vanishing into the forest.
If you're looking for money, weapons or fuel, I don't have any.  64.
How about food?
If you ask politely. My name is Benjamin Kapanay.
Danny Archer. And this is--
--Maddy Bowen. How do you do?
Very well, thank you. Chicago?
How--
--I recognize the accent. (to Solomon; in Mende) Welcome, Brother.
(in Mende; subtitles) I am Solomon Vandy, from Bo.
(in Mende; subtitles) What should I make of your companions? Solomon doesn't know how to answer. He lies badly.
(in Mende; subtitles) They are... journalists.
(in Mende; subtitles) Ah. And I suppose you are, too. Solomon looks away, ashamed. Benjamin turns to Maddy.
Might I interest you in a glass of lemonade?
Under a covered porch, they eat lunch -- served by Benjam young Mende wife and his three children.
-- I don't understand why anyone would willingly live in that cold. (MORE)
The wind off the lake. I cried every night my first winter.
How did you end up at Northwestern?
Because of President Kennedy, who else?
Excuse me?
By way of James McGrath, a young Peace Corps volunteer from Winnetka -- who found a semi-literate Mende boy and was foolish enough to believe he could benefit from higher education.
How long were you in the States?
Which time? I ended up getting my Masters at Stanford -- better climate.
But you came back?
To show my people the way. Hah. They are served a platter of vegetables by a well-mannere ten year-old boy. Benjamin's son, UCHENNA.
Thank you, Uchenna.
You built this school?
Starting in 1967. Children from all over the district find their way here. Over five hundred graduates since we began.
That's remarkable. Would you mind if I turned on my tape recorder.
I'll make you a deal, Miss Bowen -- I give you an interview and you teach at my school for a month.  116 117 66.
(laughs) I'd like that.
But you won't do it.
No.

An honest journalist, how refeshing. The truth is, I have done well to keep a low profile. This is a very dangerous part of the country with the diamond mines so close by. Solomon, meanwhile, hasn't been able to take his eyes off Benjamin's young son. The boy smiles back at him.
My son wants to be a doctor.
Very good. Where is he now? A silence.
We don't know.
I understand...
Benjamin gives them a tour: a group of eight year-olds cr around a single computer; a ten year-old girl is being ta to use an artificial limb; twelve year-old boys play cric

Many of these children were taken by the R.U.F. We have taken them back. (looks at Solomon) Some of them have been made to do horrible things. We are trying to bring them back to life. Solomon turns away to hide the surge of emotion.
They sit drinking wine. The African sunset is inimitable.
-- it was all very clear in 1964. (MORE)

Political freedom plus economic development equals happiness. But sometimes revolution leads to chaos and economic opportunity doesn't necessarily bring out the best in people. Certain personality types realized freedom could be another name for greed. (raises his glass) And here we are.
But look what you've accomplished.
And look what good it has done my country...
"There is no easy walk to freedom." We can only do the best we can.
Mandela. His best is a bit better than mine... He takes a long look at his children.
Had many attacks in the area?
I've known most of the young people in this district since they were born. The local commander is still afraid I'll come after him with my ruler.
You think because your intentions are good they'll spare you? Benjamin takes the question in stride.
My heart always told me that people are inherently good. My experience suggests otherwise. Which to believe? Benjamin turns his penetrating gaze on Archer.
What about you, Mr. Archer? In your long career as a...journalist... Would you say people are mostly good?  68. Archer stares back. The SOUND of A CHILDREN'S CHOIR...

text: The children are singing "High We Exult Thee, Realm of th Free," the national anthem of Sierra Leone. Solomon and Maddy sit with Benjamin and his family. Maddy sees Archer get up and walk away.

text: Archer stands alone. He takes a long pull from a plastic jug. Maddy steps out from the shadows.
Palm wine. Sap comes right out of the tree. He offers to her and she takes a swig. Makes a face.
You get used to it. He takes another long drink. He's pretty drunk.
Drank this as a boy.
Rhodesia. (off his look) I take notes. Indeed, her little spiral notebook is already in hand. He looks at her ~- considering -- then, what the hell...
I got sent to South Africa when the muntz overran the farm in '76.
--After you lost your parents.
(dark laugh) That's a polite way of putting it. Mum was raped. Dad was decapitated and hung from a hook in the barn.
You were, what, ten years old?
Nine. Boo-hoo.  69.
Then at eighteen you joined the army... Archer peers at her.
Want to hear about the first time I banged a journalist? She just looks at him. He takes another long drink. Relen
Yah, yah. First they had us doing dirty little jobs in the townships.
With the Security services.

You think you know about the Security services? (another dark laugh) You don't know shite. That was a picnic compared to what we did on the Moz border. Sometimes I think, ‘God will forgive us for what we did.' Then I look around and I wonder...what would God want with a Place like this? He takes another drink but the jug is empty. He tosses it
By '94 I'ma ten years vet. Then poof. No more apartheid, no more army. Thanks very much, see ya later. Truth and reconciliation. Kumbaya. He raises his middle finger in a universal gesture.
They told us we were fighting Communism. Protecting our ‘way of life.’ (a rueful laugh) It's about who gets what. Oil. Coltan. Diamonds. So one day I decided, fuck it, now I want mine.
Are you going to steal his diamond?
We have no chance in hell of getting the diamond.  70.
Doesn't answer the question.
That diamond -- whether I steal it or just take the commission -- is my ticket out of here.
To go where? Archer hasn't gotten that far in his thinking.
Benjamin drives them down roads that are little more than animal tracks. Bush pigs scamper. Chimpanzees chatter abo Solomon looks up into the canopy of forest as the sun dar in and out of view.
Dear Dia. I have found a place for your studies once you return home. Benjamin shows Maddy the hippos splashing in the river.

Do not be fooled by the movie where they wear pink skirts and dance on their toes. They are extremely dangerous, easily angered, and very fast. Benjamin's love of all that he sees is infectious. As he plays tour guide, they forget for a moment their dire circumstances and surrender to the joys of the natural wo
There is a man I want you to meet. He is a teacher. You will like him. Benjamin turns a wry eye to Archer.
What story will you be covering when I drop you in Kailahun, Mr. Archer?
Thank you for your help, Mr. Kapanay. I won't forget it.
I hope the story will end the way you want it to.  71.
guarded by TWO TWELVE YEAR-OLD CHILD SOLDIERS.
Keep going.
What--?
Drive right at them. They'll panic. Instead Benjamin slows the car.

are indeed children. One wears a Michael Jordan jersey, t other has skateboard stickers on his Ingram submachine gu But their eyes are glazed and deadened.

I am Dead Body. Who dis mothafuckah?

Only R.U.F on da road!

122 123 125 72. He leans over and STOMPS ON THE GAS PEDAL. The car LURCHE FORWARD, knocking aside the other boy. Archer has to practically straddle the wounded man to speed away.

(weakly) You...said...not to talk.
A fucking comedian. He pushes the old car's accelerator to its limit.
